hints.content:
The $\purpleD{\text{numerator}}$ is the number of equal parts being counted.

The $\blueD{\text{denominator}}$ is the number of equal parts in **one** whole. 

$\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{numerator}}}{\blueD{\text{denominator}}}$

The $\blueD{\text{denominator}}$ is $\blueD6$, so we need $\blueD6$ equal pieces in each whole.

The $\purpleD{\text{numerator}}$ is $\purpleD{11}$, so we need $\purpleD{11}$ equal parts shaded.

The following images show $\dfrac{11}6$ shaded:


[[☃ image 1]]


[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: Three squares. Each square is divided into 6 equal parts. The first square has 4 parts shaded. The second square has 2 parts shaded. The third square has 5 parts shaded. !
Three squares. Each square is divided into 6 equal parts. The first square has 3 parts shaded. The second square has 4 parts shaded. The third square has 4 parts shaded. !

question.content:
Each large square represents $1$ whole.

**Which images show $\dfrac{11}6$ shaded?**

[[☃ radio 2]]

choices.content: ![Three squares. Each square is divided into 6 equal parts. The first square has 4 parts shaded. The second square has 2 parts shaded. The third square has 5 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/793237a27054c88836db12efafe1759c08d99aaa)

![Three squares. Each square is divided into 6 equal parts. The first square has 3 parts shaded. The second square has 4 parts shaded. The third square has 4 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9c523a22422d6e085d13a79c7eada41649f780a0)
![Two squares. Each square is divided into 6 parts. Both squares have 6 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/5b15e401ad4855e816597d2f5a083a884bb959f6)
![Three squares. Each square is divided into 6 parts. Each square has 5 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/02fdbdfb3bb562a3c19d8eb6fef2a21282104cc4)
